Osteoporosis: clinical evaluation.

questionList.questionText: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office for a preventive visit.  She has been feeling well but is concerned about osteoporosis because her older friend had a hip fracture last year and now must use a walker.  The patient has no medical problems and never has had a fracture or surgery.  Menopause occurred at age 50.  She has never smoked and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Her parents and siblings have had no osteoporotic fractures.  Height is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in), weight is 84 kg (185 lb) and BMI is 31 kg/m2.  The remainder of the physical examination is normal.  The patient is instructed to initiate a weight-bearing exercise regimen.  Which of the following is the most appropriate osteoporosis screening test for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Osteoporosis risk factors

Nonmodifiable

  • Advanced age
  • Postmenopausal
  • Low body weight
  • White or Asian
  • Malabsorption disorder
  • Hypercortisolism, hyperthyroidism, hyperparathyroidism
  • Inflammatory disorder (eg, rheumatoid arthritis)
  • Chronic liver or kidney disease

Modifiable

  • Smoking
  • Excessive alcohol intake
  • Sedentary lifestyle
  • Medications (eg, glucocorticoids, anticonvulsants)
  • Vitamin D deficiency, inadequate calcium intake
  • Estrogen deficiency (eg, premature menopause, oophorectomy)

Other than timely menopause, this patient has no risk factors for osteoporotic fractures and is at average risk for osteoporosis.  Such patients should be screened using dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) at age 65, as recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force.

DXA is the preferred screening test for osteoporosis.  It uses scattering of x-ray by bone to measure 2-dimensional density (in g/cm2).  The result is reported as a T-score, which is the standard deviations above/below the mean for a healthy young adult at peak bone density; by convention, osteoporosis is a T-score ≤-2.5, whereas osteopenia is a T-score between -1 and -2.5.

If the patient has multiple risk factors for osteoporosis (eg, weight <58 kg [127 lb], smoking, parental history of hip fracture, early menopause), then the risk should be estimated using the FRAX fracture risk assessment tool.  If the risk is high enough, then osteoporosis screening at an earlier age may be appropriate (Choices A and C).

(Choices D, E, and F)  Skeletal survey is a plain x-ray of the entire skeleton, and is typically used in adults to evaluate nonlocalized bone disease (eg, multiple myeloma, disseminated infection).  Although skeletal survey may detect osteoporotic fractures and can sometimes detect severe osteoporotic bone loss, it is nonquantitative and has low sensitivity for osteoporosis; DXA is the preferred screening test.

Educational objective:
Screening for osteoporosis with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry is recommended in all women age >65 and for younger women with an equivalent risk of osteoporotic fracture.

questionList.questionText: A 63-year-old woman comes to the office due to back pain.  The patient works as a postal carrier, and the pain started 2 days ago while she was lifting a heavy package on the job.  She has had no lower extremity weakness or sensory symptoms.  She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily.  The patient reports, "The pain is too much for me to do my job; I think I need to take a few days off work."  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, and pulse is 80/min.  Physical examination shows paravertebral tenderness localized to the L3 level on the right side.  There is no tenderness over the spine.  Lower extremity strength is 5/5, and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ and symmetric.  With the patient supine and the knee extended, flexion of the right hip elicits achy pain behind the right thigh up to the knee.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Lumbosacral strain

Causes

  • Strain of paraspinal muscles, tendons, intervertebral ligaments
  • Sudden or unbalanced muscle contraction (eg, lifting, twisting)
  • Risk factors: obesity, spinal deformity or degeneration, muscle weakness

Clinical features

  • Pain in lumbar area; may radiate to buttocks, hips, thighs (above knee)
  • Paraspinal tenderness
  • No neurologic deficits; negative straight-leg raising test

Management

  • Moderate activity
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Nonbenzodiazepine muscle relaxants

This patient has acute low back pain associated with paraspinal tenderness and no neurologic deficits, findings consistent with lumbosacral strain (LSS).  LSS is the most common cause of back pain and is often triggered by twisting, lifting, or physical exertion.  Risk factors include obesity, spinal deformity (eg, scoliosis), degenerative spinal changes, and muscle weakness/deconditioning.

LSS is characterized by pain in the lumbar paravertebral muscles that does not radiate below the level of the knee (as in this patient).  In contrast, the pain in lumbosacral radiculopathy, which is most commonly caused by a herniated intervertebral disc, classically radiates down the posterolateral leg to the foot.  Most patients with lumbosacral radiculopathy (rather than LSS) also have a positive straight-leg raising test; in this test, flexion of the hip with the knee extended causes irritation to the spinal nerve root (L5 or S1), eliciting burning or shooting pain in a radicular distribution.  Hamstring tension (ie, achy pain in the posterior thigh and knee), as in this patient, is a nonspecific finding and does not indicate radicular pain (ie, is consided a negative straight-leg raising test) (Choice A).

Most cases of LSS improve spontaneously and are treated symptomatically with heat, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and early mobilization.  No additional work-up is usually needed.

(Choice C)  Patients with back pain commonly express a desire to take time off work, believing that rest is needed for proper recovery.  This alone does not indicate malingering unless there is evidence of deception (eg, inconsistent or falsified history) or exaggeration (eg, dramatic expression of tenderness to light palpation over a broad region).  This patient has no exaggerated findings, and her history and examination are typical for LSS.

(Choice D)  Cancer frequently metastasizes to the spine due to slow blood flow through the vertebral plexus, which allows the deposition of malignant cells.  However, spinal metastasis generally causes vertebral pain (not just in the paraspinal muscles) that is worse at night and unrelieved by rest.

(Choice E)  Osteoporotic compression fracture can occur in postmenopausal women during heavy lifting or twisting.  However, tenderness is generally localized to the vertebral body rather than to the paraspinal muscles alone.

Educational objective:
Lumbosacral strain is the most common cause of acute back pain.  It is often triggered by twisting, lifting, or physical exertion.  The pain and tenderness are localized primarily to the lumbar paraspinal area but may radiate to the buttocks, hips, and thighs.  The straight-leg raising test and neurologic examination are typically normal.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man comes to the office due to intermittent pain and numbness in the right hand for the past several months.  The symptoms occur primarily at night and occasionally wake the patient.  Shaking the hand or holding it in a dependent position briefly relieves the pain.  The patient works as a carpenter.  He has a 20-pack-year smoking history but does not use alcohol or recreational drugs.  Vital signs are normal.  BMI is 36 kg/m2.  Examination shows normal range of motion in the wrists and digits.  Sensation is decreased to pinprick in the thumb and index finger.  Biceps, triceps, and brachioradialis reflexes are normal.  There is no muscle atrophy.  Phalen and Tinel tests do not provoke symptoms.  The remainder of the examination is normal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
The carpal tunnel is bounded by the carpal bones and transverse carpal ligament.  It contains the median nerve, along with the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus and superficialis and the flexor pollicis longus.  Compression of the nerve causes carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), which is characterized by pain and paresthesia that may involve all or part of the first 3½ digits.  Symptoms are often intermittent and worse at night and may be provoked by repetitive or forceful hand and wrist use, as in this patient who is a carpenter.  Patients may report relief from shaking the hand.

The diagnosis of CTS is usually made on clinical grounds.  Provocative maneuvers (eg, Phalen and Tinel tests) often reproduce the symptoms but have limited sensitivity and specificity.  If examination findings are inconclusive, the diagnosis can be confirmed with nerve conduction studies, which have high sensitivity and specificity for CTS.  Typical findings include slowed conduction velocities in the median nerve across the wrist.  Imaging is not routinely indicated, although ultrasound may show swelling of the median nerve.

(Choice A)  CT scan of the chest can confirm malignancy at the superior pulmonary sulcus (ie, Pancoast tumor), which can cause hand pain and paresthesia due to compression of the C8-T2 nerve roots.  However, the pain is typically constant and progressive; does not follow the distribution of the median nerve; and is often associated with shoulder pain, Horner syndrome (ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis), and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.

(Choice B)  MRI of the cervical spine is indicated to evaluate cervical radiculopathy (eg, neck and upper arm pain, diminished reflexes) or cervical spondylotic myelopathy (eg, bilateral upper motor neuron weakness, bilateral sensory deficits).

(Choices C and E)  MRI allows visualization of the contents of the carpal tunnel but is indicated primarily when a mass is suspected or nerve conduction studies are nondiagnostic.  X-ray may be considered in patients with a history of significant trauma or evidence of advanced rheumatoid or osteoarthritis (eg, decreased range of motion, wrist joint deformity) but cannot confirm or exclude the diagnosis of CTS.

Educational objective:
Median nerve compression at the wrist causes carpal tunnel syndrome, which is characterized by pain and paresthesia in the first 3½ digits or any part of that distribution.  The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds, but nerve conduction studies can help confirm the diagnosis, especially when examination findings are inconclusive.

questionList.title: Median nerve injury

questionList.questionText: A 37-year-old man comes to the office due to a 2-month history of left-sided groin pain.  The patient has a progressive, achy pain that is present at rest and worse with ambulation and weight bearing.  He was treated for poison ivy dermatitis with a 5-day course of oral prednisone a year ago but has had no other medical conditions and takes no medications.  The patient drinks 5 or 6 alcoholic beverages a day.  He works as a gardener for a landscaping service and plays soccer twice a week.  Vital signs are normal.  BMI is 24 kg/m2.  On examination, the patient appears mildly uncomfortable and anxious.  Examination of the hip and groin shows no erythema, warmth, or swelling.  Active and passive range of motion at the left hip is decreased in extension, abduction, and internal and external rotation.  X-ray of the hip is shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is most likely contributing to this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Adult hip osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis)

Clinical presentation

  • Chronic/progressive groin, thigh, buttock pain
  • Decreased ROM: abduction, internal rotation

Pathogenesis

  • Macro- or microvascular occlusion, bone necrosis
  • Trabecular thinning & collapse of femoral head

Risk factors

  • Femoral head fracture (arterial disruption)
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Excessive alcohol use
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

Diagnosis

  • X-ray (low sensitivity): subchondral sclerosis,
    loss of sphericity
  • MRI: serpiginous low-intensity lines (T1 images); bone marrow edema

ROM = range of motion.

This patient has osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) of the femoral head, presenting with chronic groin pain and decreased range of motion.  The diagnosis is confirmed on x-ray showing flattening and patchy sclerosis of the femoral head; x-ray has low sensitivity, and MRI, which can visualize the boundary between normal and ischemic bone, may be performed if x-ray is nondiagnostic.

Osteonecrosis is caused by disruption of perfusion due to macro- or microvascular occlusion, endothelial dysfunction, or increased intraosseous pressure.  Excessive alcohol intake is a major risk factor.  The risk is proportionate to the amount and duration of use, with most cases occurring in individuals consuming ≥24 drinks/week (≥400 mL/week) for ≥8 years.  Alcohol-related osteonecrosis is likely due to fat embolism in the setting of hyperlipidemia, particularly hypertriglyceridemia; additional contributing factors include adipocyte hypertrophy in the marrow with resulting venous stasis.

(Choice A)  Autoimmune arthritis, primarily rheumatoid arthritis (RA), can affect the hip and cause chronic pain and loss of motion.  However, monoarticular hip RA is rare, and most patients have polyarticular disease.  In addition, the typical x-ray findings of RA (eg, periarticular bony erosions and osteopenia, concentric loss of joint space) are not present in this patient; he has no erythema, warmth, or swelling to suggest inflammatory synovitis.

(Choice C)  Excess loading of the hip due to obesity or mechanical deformity can lead to osteoarthritis (OA).  Although OA can cause chronic hip pain, x-ray typically shows decreased joint space and periarticular osteophytes.  This young man with a normal BMI is unlikely to have OA.

(Choice D)  Systemic corticosteroid use is a major risk factor for osteonecrosis.  However, it is seen primarily in patients receiving chronic, supraphysiologic doses.  The risk from a single short course of prednisone, like this patient had, is very low, as is the risk from nonsystemic (eg, inhaled, intraarticular) corticosteroids.

(Choice E)  Human leukocyte antigen-B27 serotype is a risk factor for ankylosing spondylitis and psoriatic arthritis.  Ankylosing spondylitis can affect the hip, but most patients have chronic back and sacroiliac pain.  Psoriatic arthritis can present as a distal, small-joint arthritis; mixed oligoarthritis; or spondyloarthropathy.  Large-joint monarthritis is rare.

Educational objective:
Osteonecrosis of the femoral head presents with chronic groin pain and decreased hip range of motion.  It is caused by disruption of perfusion due to vascular occlusion, endothelial dysfunction, or increased intraosseous pressure.  Excessive alcohol use is a major risk factor, with the risk proportionate to the amount and duration of use.
